text: Resolution adopted by the General Assembly on 24 December 2024
[on the report of the Fifth Committee (A/79/650, para. 6)]
79/254.	Administration of justice at the United Nations
The General Assembly,

Recalling section XI of its resolution 55/258 of 14 June 2001 and its resolutions 57/307 of 15 April 2003, 59/266 of 23 December 2004, 59/283 of 13 April 2005, 61/261 of 4 April 2007, 62/228 of 22 December 2007, 63/253 of 24 December 2008, 64/233 of 22 December 2009, 65/251 of 24 December 2010, 66/237 of 24 December 2011, 67/241 of 24 December 2012, 68/254 of 27 December 2013, 69/203 of 18 December 2014, 70/112 of 14 December 2015, 71/266 of 23 December 2016, 72/256 of 24 December 2017, 73/276 of 22 December 2018, 74/258 of 27 December 2019, 75/248 of 31 December 2020, 76/242 of 24 December 2021, 77/260 of 30 December 2022 and 78/248 of 22 December 2023,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* section XI of its resolution 55/258 of 14 June 2001 and its resolutions 57/307 of 15 April 2003, 59/266 of 23 December 2004, 59/283 of 13 April 2005, 61/261 of 4 April 2007, 62/228 of 22 December 2007, 63/253 of 24 December 2008, 64/233 of 22 December 2009, 65/251 of 24 December 2010, 66/237 of 24 December 2011, 67/241 of 24 December 2012, 68/254 of 27 December 2013, 69/203 of 18 December 2014, 70/112 of 14 December 2015, 71/266 of 23 December 2016, 72/256 of 24 December 2017, 73/276 of 22 December 2018, 74/258 of 27 December 2019, 75/248 of 31 December 2020, 76/242 of 24 December 2021, 77/260 of 30 December 2022 and 78/248 of 22 December 2023,

text: Having considered the reports of the Secretary-General on administration of justice at the United Nations and on the activities of the Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services, the report of the Internal Justice Council on administration of justice at the United Nations and the related report of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions, as well as the letter dated 22 November 2024 from the President of the General Assembly addressed to the Chair of the Fifth Committee,

Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions

textWithHighlights: *Having considered* the reports of the {{Secretary-General}} on administration of justice at the {{United Nations}} and on the activities of the {{Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services}}, the report of the {{Internal Justice Council}} on administration of justice at the {{United Nations}} and the related report of the {{Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions}}, as well as the letter dated 22 November 2024 from the {{President of the General Assembly}} addressed to the Chair of the {{Fifth Committee}},
uncertainties: Classified ACABQ and Fifth Committee as 'other' since they are not explicitly listed in the provided entity list; used ACABQ abbreviation for normalization.

text: Having also considered the note by the Secretary-General drawing attention to the report of the Joint Inspection Unit on the review of the internal pre-tribunal-stage appeal mechanisms available to staff of the United Nations system organizations, as well as the comments of the Secretary-General and of the United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination thereon,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination

textWithHighlights: *Having also considered* the note by the {{Secretary-General}} drawing attention to the report of the {{Joint Inspection Unit}} on the review of the internal pre-tribunal-stage appeal mechanisms available to staff of the {{United Nations system organizations}}, as well as the comments of the {{Secretary-General}} and of the {{United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination}} thereon,
uncertainties: Treated "United Nations system organizations" as the mentioned entity "UN System" in normalized form; the text refers generically to organizations within the UN system rather than a specific body.

text: Takes note of the report of the Secretary-General on administration of justice at the United Nations and on the activities of the Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services, the report of the Internal Justice Council on administration of justice at the United Nations and the related report of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services
Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions

textWithHighlights: *Takes note* of the report of the {{Secretary-General}} on administration of justice at the United Nations and on the activities of the {{Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services}}, the report of the {{Internal Justice Council}} on administration of justice at the United Nations and the related report of the {{Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions}};

text: Endorses the conclusions and recommendations contained in the report of the Advisory Committee, subject to the provisions of the present resolution;
textWithHighlights: *Endorses* the conclusions and recommendations contained in the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, subject to the provisions of the present resolution;
uncertainties: Classified the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (referred to here as 'Advisory Committee') as 'other' since it is not explicitly listed among predefined entities. No explicit assignee is mentioned; GA is the implicit actor.

text: Notes with appreciation the report of the Joint Inspection Unit on the review of the internal pre-tribunal-stage appeal mechanisms available to staff of the United Nations system organizations, and stresses that its findings shall not result in changes to the system of administration of justice, established by the General Assembly in resolutions 61/261, 62/228 and 63/253;
textWithHighlights: *Notes with appreciation* the report of the {{Joint Inspection Unit}} on the review of the internal pre-tribunal-stage appeal mechanisms available to staff of the {{United Nations system organizations}}, and *stresses* that its findings shall not result in changes to the system of administration of justice, established by the {{General Assembly}} in resolutions 61/261, 62/228 and 63/253;

text: System of administration of justice
Emphasizes the importance of the principle of judicial independence in the system of administration of justice;
textWithHighlights: *Emphasizes* the importance of the principle of judicial independence in the system of administration of justice;

text: Stresses the importance of ensuring access for all staff members to the system of administration of justice, regardless of their duty station;
textWithHighlights: *Stresses* the importance of ensuring access for all staff members to the system of administration of justice, regardless of their duty station;

text: Acknowledges the evolving nature of the system of administration of justice and the need to carefully monitor its implementation to ensure that it remains within the parameters set out by the General Assembly;
textWithHighlights: *Acknowledges* the evolving nature of the system of administration of justice and the need to carefully monitor its implementation to ensure that it remains within the parameters set out by the {{General Assembly}};

text: Reaffirms its decision, contained in paragraph 4 of its resolution 61/261, to establish a new, independent, transparent, professionalized, adequately resourced and decentralized system of administration of justice consistent with the relevant rules of international law and the principles of the rule of law and due process to ensure respect for the rights and obligations of staff members and the accountability of managers and staff members alike;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* its decision, contained in paragraph 4 of its resolution 61/261, to establish a new, independent, transparent, professionalized, adequately resourced and decentralized system of administration of justice consistent with the relevant rules of international law and the principles of the rule of law and due process to ensure respect for the rights and obligations of staff members and the accountability of managers and staff members alike;
uncertainties: Considered whether to mark "system of administration of justice" (establish) as a deliverable, but since the paragraph only reaffirms a prior decision and assigns no actor, it was left out.

text: Requests the Secretary-General to continue to ensure a strong culture of accountability throughout the Secretariat, in particular with proactive and transparent application of the United Nations three-pillared approach to the management of misconduct, namely, prevention, enforcement and remedial action, and to ensure access to effective remedies for all categories of personnel;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Application of three-pillared approach to misconduct management
deliverables.deliverable: application of the United Nations three-pillared approach

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Access to effective remedies for all personnel

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to continue to ensure a strong culture of accountability throughout the {{Secretariat}}, in particular with proactive and transparent [[application of the United Nations three-pillared approach]] to the management of misconduct, namely, prevention, enforcement and remedial action, and to ensure [[access to effective remedies]] for all categories of personnel;

text: Stresses that the system of administration of justice must work in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations and the legal and regulatory framework approved by the General Assembly, and reaffirms that the United Nations Dispute Tribunal and the United Nations Appeals Tribunal shall exercise their powers according to their respective statutes;
textWithHighlights: *Stresses* that the system of administration of justice must work in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations and the legal and regulatory framework approved by the {{General Assembly}}, and *reaffirms* that the {{United Nations Dispute Tribunal}} and the {{United Nations Appeals Tribunal}} shall exercise their powers according to their respective statutes;
uncertainties: Classified UNDT and UNAT as 'other' mentioned entities; they are not in the provided entity list. Interpreted the paragraph as reinforcing rather than directive, despite the clause 'shall exercise their powers' being reaffirmed.

text: Welcomes the comprehensive assessment of the functioning of the system of administration of justice, and requests the Secretary-General to undertake comprehensive assessments and reviews of the system of administration of justice on a five-year cycle and to submit cost-efficient proposals on establishing a single database for collecting and analysing data from various justice system mechanisms, entities, funds and programmes in the context of the next report;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Comprehensive assessments of the UN administration of justice system (five-year cycle)
Comprehensive reviews of the UN administration of justice system (five-year cycle)
Cost-efficient proposals to establish a single justice-system database

textWithHighlights: *Welcomes* the comprehensive assessment of the functioning of the system of administration of justice, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to undertake comprehensive [[assessments]] and [[reviews]] of the system of administration of justice on a five-year cycle and to submit cost-efficient [[proposals]] on establishing a single database for collecting and analysing data from various justice system mechanisms, entities, {{funds}} and {{programmes}} in the context of the next report;
uncertainties: Assumed that “funds and programmes” refers to UN funds and programmes. Treated “assessments” and “reviews” as deliverables of type review, and “proposals” as recommendations rather than infrastructure since the task is to submit proposals on establishing a database.

text: Notes that the majority of staff grievances are addressed at early stages by the Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services, the Office of Staff Legal Assistance and the management evaluation function and that the data fluctuate from year to year and over time, with some periods showing more stability, and requests the Secretary-General to ensure continuous identification of additional relevant trends in the context of more systemic collection of data from all entities and various actors of the system;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: identification of trends

textWithHighlights: *Notes* that the majority of staff grievances are addressed at early stages by the {{Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services}}, the {{Office of Staff Legal Assistance}} and the management evaluation function and that the data fluctuate from year to year and over time, with some periods showing more stability, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to ensure continuous [[identification of additional relevant trends]] in the context of more systemic collection of data from all entities and various actors of the system;
uncertainties: OSLA (Office of Staff Legal Assistance) is not explicitly listed among predefined entities; treated as a UN Secretariat entity with normalized abbreviation 'OSLA'.

text: Notes with appreciation that the Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services, the Management Advice and Evaluation Section and the Office of Staff Legal Assistance have contributed significantly by enabling the resolution of work-related disputes and by serving as filtering mechanisms to reduce litigation before the Tribunals;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services

textWithHighlights: *Notes with appreciation* that the {{Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services}}, the {{Management Advice and Evaluation Section}} and the {{Office of Staff Legal Assistance}} have contributed significantly by enabling the resolution of work-related disputes and by serving as filtering mechanisms to reduce litigation before the Tribunals;
uncertainties: The official abbreviation for Management Advice and Evaluation Section is assumed as MAES; adjust if a different official acronym is used in the source resolution.

text: Recalls paragraph 8 of the report of the Advisory Committee, and requests the Secretary-General to intensify his efforts to implement multilingualism within the system of administration of justice, and also requests the Secretary-General to report on his efforts to continue to promote multilingualism in the system of administration of justice in the context of his future reports;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Implement multilingualism in the UN administration of justice system
Report on efforts to promote multilingualism in the UN administration of justice system

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraph 8 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to intensify his efforts to [[implement multilingualism]] within the system of administration of justice, and also *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to [[report]] on his efforts to continue to promote multilingualism in the system of administration of justice in the context of his future reports;
uncertainties: "Advisory Committee" is likely the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (ACABQ).

text: Also recalls paragraph 36 of its resolution 75/248, and reaffirms the requirement for the Internal Justice Council to provide a detailed programme of work for each calendar year as part of its annual report, for approval by the General Assembly;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: annual programme of work

textWithHighlights: Also *recalls* paragraph 36 of its resolution 75/248, and *reaffirms* the requirement for the <<Internal Justice Council>> to provide a [[detailed programme of work]] for each calendar year as part of its annual report, for approval by the {{General Assembly}};
uncertainties: Classifying “programme of work” as a strategy vs. linking it to the annual report (report) is somewhat ambiguous. Treated here as a strategy deliverable included within the report. Also, using a reinforcing verb to assign the obligation to the Internal Justice Council assumes reaffirmation of an existing requirement implies an assignee.

text: Further recalls paragraph 38 of the report of the Advisory Committee, and encourages the entities of the system of administration of justice to enhance consultation and communication across the system, aimed at fostering a comprehensive understanding, and improving overall operational efficiency;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (ACABQ)

assignees.assignee: entities of the system of administration of justice

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: consultation
communication

textWithHighlights: *Further recalls* paragraph 38 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, and *encourages* the <<entities of the system of administration of justice>> to enhance [[consultation]] and [[communication]] across the system, aimed at fostering a comprehensive understanding, and improving overall operational efficiency;
uncertainties: The assignee "entities of the system of administration of justice" is normalized to UN Secretariat; this could alternatively be interpreted as a subset of Secretariat bodies (e.g., OAJ, OSLA, OMS). The deliverables "consultation" and "communication" are somewhat broad; classified respectively as meeting and information_sharing.

text: Welcomes the continued and increased efforts related to outreach activities reported by the different parts of the system of administration of justice, and urges the Secretary-General to provide information on the role and functioning of the various parts of the system of administration of justice, and the possibilities it offered to address work-related complaints;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Information on role and functioning of system of administration of justice

textWithHighlights: *Welcomes* the continued and increased efforts related to outreach activities reported by the different parts of the system of administration of justice, and *urges* the <<Secretary-General>> to [[provide information]] on the role and functioning of the various parts of the system of administration of justice, and the possibilities it offered to address work-related complaints;
uncertainties: "Provide information" could alternatively be categorized as a report or update, but it is phrased broadly, so it is classified as information_sharing.

text: Reiterates its requests to the Secretary-General to refine the strategic action plan for addressing racism and promoting dignity for all in the United Nations Secretariat and stresses that continuous learning and dialogue on racism is essential to embed an anti-racist awareness culture in the Organization and transform organizational culture, encourages the Secretary-General to continue working closely with the Anti-Racism Office, and requests the Secretary-General to continue providing observations and data on the trends and patterns of racism and racial discrimination and remedial actions taken within the Organization;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: refined strategic action plan on anti-racism in UN Secretariat
observations and data on racism trends and patterns, and remedial actions

textWithHighlights: *Reiterates* its requests to the <<Secretary-General>> to [[refine the strategic action plan]] for addressing racism and promoting dignity for all in the {{United Nations Secretariat}} and *stresses* that continuous learning and dialogue on racism is essential to embed an anti-racist awareness culture in the {{Organization}} and transform organizational culture, *encourages* the <<Secretary-General>> to continue working closely with the {{Anti-Racism Office}}, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to continue providing [[observations and data]] on the trends and patterns of racism and racial discrimination and remedial actions taken within the {{Organization}};
uncertainties:
- The first clause uses 'reiterates its requests to the Secretary-General to refine...', where 'requests' is a noun; we still associated the assignee (UN Secretary-General) and deliverable (refine the strategic action plan) with the reinforcing verb 'reiterates'.
- For 'requests ... to continue providing observations and data', the deliverable type was classified as 'analysis'; it could also be interpreted as 'information_sharing' depending on implementation.

text: Reiterates that retaliation against complainants or staff appearing as witnesses constitutes misconduct, notes with appreciation the policy on protection against retaliation for reporting misconduct and for cooperating with duly authorized audits or investigations, as well as the efforts to continuously improve the framework for protection from retaliation, and in this regard requests the Secretary-General to provide information on the implementation of the policy for all categories of personnel covered in his next report;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Information on implementation of protection against retaliation policy
deliverables.deliverable: information on the implementation of the policy

textWithHighlights: *Reiterates* that retaliation against complainants or staff appearing as witnesses constitutes misconduct, *notes with appreciation* the policy on protection against retaliation for reporting misconduct and for cooperating with duly authorized audits or investigations, as well as the efforts to continuously improve the framework for protection from retaliation, and in this regard *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to provide [[information on the implementation of the policy]] for all categories of personnel covered in his next report;

text: Informal system
Recognizes that the informal system of administration of justice is an efficient and effective option both for staff who seek redress of grievances and for the participation of managers;
textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* that the informal system of administration of justice is an efficient and effective option both for staff who seek redress of grievances and for the participation of managers;

text: Reaffirms that the informal resolution of conflict is a crucial element of the system of administration of justice, emphasizes that all possible use should be made of the informal system in order to avoid unnecessary litigation, without prejudice to the basic right of staff members to access the formal system, and encourages recourse to the informal resolution of disputes;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* that the informal resolution of conflict is a crucial element of the system of administration of justice, *emphasizes* that all possible use should be made of the informal system in order to avoid unnecessary litigation, without prejudice to the basic right of staff members to access the formal system, and *encourages* recourse to the informal resolution of disputes;
uncertainties: "encourages" has no explicit assignee specified; no concrete deliverables are identified.

text: Recognizes mediation as a core part of the work of the Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services and as a cost-effective method of informal conflict resolution, underlines the importance of increasing the use of mediation services, and encourages improved communication between all parts of the system of administration of justice;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services

textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* mediation as a core part of the work of the {{Office of the United Nations Ombudsman and Mediation Services}} and as a cost-effective method of informal conflict resolution, *underlines* the importance of increasing the use of mediation services, and *encourages* improved communication between all parts of the system of administration of justice;
uncertainties: No explicit assignee is provided for the directive verb "encourages". Considered marking "improved communication" as a deliverable (information_sharing) but judged it too vague to include.

text: Notes the informal first approach within the system of administration of justice;
textWithHighlights: *Notes* the informal first approach within the system of administration of justice;

text: Formal system
Recognizes the ongoing positive contribution of the Office of Staff Legal Assistance to the system of administration of justice;
textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* the ongoing positive contribution of the {{Office of Staff Legal Assistance}} to the system of administration of justice;

text: Welcomes the efforts made by the United Nations Dispute Tribunal to reduce the number of pending and ageing cases, stresses the importance of continued implementation of all measures to avoid backlog of cases, with priority for cases which are pending for over 400 days, and requests the Secretary-General to continuously monitor cases via the case disposal plan and real-time case-tracking dashboard;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: monitor cases

textWithHighlights: *Welcomes* the efforts made by the {{United Nations Dispute Tribunal}} to reduce the number of pending and ageing cases, *stresses* the importance of continued implementation of all measures to avoid backlog of cases, with priority for cases which are pending for over 400 days, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to continuously [[monitor cases]] via the case disposal plan and real-time case-tracking dashboard;
uncertainties: The deliverable 'monitor cases' could arguably be categorized as 'analysis' instead of 'review' since it involves ongoing tracking.

text: Recalls paragraph 30 of the report of the Advisory Committee, decides to extend the voluntary funding mechanism for 10 years, and requests the Secretary-General to provide a detailed overview every 5 years of the functioning of the mechanism, including opt-out rates, total contributions received from staff, services provided and satisfaction thereof, without prejudice to the current reporting arrangements, to ensure its continued efficiency, effectiveness, transparency and accountability;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Extension of voluntary funding mechanism (10 years)
Five-year report on functioning of the mechanism

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraph 30 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, *decides* to [[extend the voluntary funding mechanism]] for 10 years, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to provide a [[detailed overview every 5 years]] of the functioning of the mechanism, including opt-out rates, total contributions received from staff, services provided and satisfaction thereof, without prejudice to the current reporting arrangements, to ensure its continued efficiency, effectiveness, transparency and accountability;
uncertainties: "Advisory Committee" likely refers to ACABQ; normalized as "Other (Other United Nations Bodies)" due to lack of a specific entry.

text: Notes the recommendation of the Internal Justice Council to initiate an 18-month pilot programme on judicial mediation, and requests the Secretary-General to evaluate possible cost-efficient procedural optimization mechanisms, in a manner consistent with article 19 (1) of the rules of procedure of the Dispute Tribunal, such as conciliatory hearings conditional on the agreement of both parties to a complaint, within existing resources, while integrating the views of all relevant stakeholders, including the Dispute Tribunal and the Appeals Tribunal;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Evaluation of procedural optimization mechanisms

textWithHighlights: *Notes* the recommendation of the {{Internal Justice Council}} to initiate an 18-month pilot programme on judicial mediation, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to [[evaluate]] possible cost-efficient procedural optimization mechanisms, in a manner consistent with article 19 (1) of the rules of procedure of the {{Dispute Tribunal}}, such as conciliatory hearings conditional on the agreement of both parties to a complaint, within existing resources, while integrating the views of all relevant stakeholders, including the {{Dispute Tribunal}} and the {{Appeals Tribunal}};

text: Other issues

Invites the Sixth Committee to consider the legal aspects of the report to be submitted by the Secretary-General, without prejudice to the role of the Fifth Committee as the Main Committee entrusted with responsibilities for administrative and budgetary matters;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Legal analysis of SG report

textWithHighlights: *Invites* the <<Sixth Committee>> to consider the [[legal aspects]] of the report to be submitted by the {{Secretary-General}}, without prejudice to the role of the {{Fifth Committee}} as the Main Committee entrusted with responsibilities for administrative and budgetary matters;
uncertainties: Sixth and Fifth Committees are not in the provided entity list; categorized as 'other'. Deliverable classified as 'analysis' (could also be seen as a 'review').

text: Notes the recommendation of the Internal Justice Council on the issuance of reinstatement, and requests the Secretary-General to include, in the context of his next report, information on the current use of reinstatement and compensation where the contested administrative decision concerns appointment, promotion or termination;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Information on reinstatement and compensation
deliverables.deliverable: information on the current use of reinstatement and compensation

textWithHighlights: *Notes* the recommendation of the {{Internal Justice Council}} on the issuance of reinstatement, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to include, in the context of his next report, [[information on the current use of reinstatement and compensation]] where the contested administrative decision concerns appointment, promotion or termination;
uncertainties: Classified Internal Justice Council as 'other' since it is not in the provided entity list. The deliverable is treated as an 'update' because it is information to be included in the Secretary-General’s next report rather than a standalone report.

text: Recalls that the respective views of the Appeals Tribunal and the Dispute Tribunal had previously been included as annexes to the report of the Internal Justice Council, notes the usefulness of such information and stresses that the Council can help to ensure independence, professionalism and accountability in the system of administrative of justice, and requests the Secretary-General to entrust the Council with including the views of both the Dispute Tribunal and the Appeals Tribunal in its report at the future sessions of the General Assembly.

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Include views of UNDT and UNAT in IJC report

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* that the respective views of the {{Appeals Tribunal}} and the {{Dispute Tribunal}} had previously been included as annexes to the report of the {{Internal Justice Council}}, *notes* the usefulness of such information and *stresses* that the {{Council}} can help to ensure independence, professionalism and accountability in the system of administrative of justice, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to entrust the {{Council}} with [[including the views]] of both the {{Dispute Tribunal}} and the {{Appeals Tribunal}} in its report at the future sessions of the {{General Assembly}}.
uncertainties: Classified the deliverable under 'report' since the action is to include specific views in future reports; alternatively, this could be seen as information-sharing. The Appeals Tribunal, Dispute Tribunal, and Internal Justice Council are mapped as 'other' entities as they are not listed explicitly in the provided entity list.
